metadata.title: Elbow Dislocation, Adult
description: The elbow joint is stabilized by bony articulations and ligaments and stabilized dynamically by attached muscles. A strong force is required to disrupt the joint. Although the elbow joint is relatively stable, posterior elbow dislocations are fairly common, ranking second in major dislocations after the shoulder(8)

The most common simple elbow dislocations are posterolateral and progress from medial ligament tears. Dislocations are considered simple when there is no fracture beyond small avulsion fractures (1–2 mm)(10)

Elbow dislocation is classified by the direction of displacement of the proximal ulna (i.e., whether posterior or anterior) relative to the distal humerus. Posterolateral dislocation is the most common displacement direction. Rarely, the humerus may separate the radius and ulna, producing a divergent dislocation; these are typically pediatric injuries(8)

Severe ligament tears (e.g., resulting in joint instability) and periarticular fractures often complicate elbow dislocation in adults (For more information on elbow fractures, see Clinical Review…Fracture, Elbow  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708543)

Surgical treatment usually is required for unstable dislocation; i.e., one that cannot be reduced externally. Following open reduction and soft tissue repair, if the elbow remains unstable an external fixator (static or hinged) may be used to maintain the reduction. If a hinged fixator is used, then early mobilization may be allowed(7)

After a standard of 3 to 10 days immobilization,rehabilitation therapists attempt to minimize the development of contracture and chronic elbow stiffness with gentle ROM exercises while maintaining elbow joint stability(1) or application of equipment . Desired Outcomes/Outcome Measures

ICD-10 codes.S53: Dislocation and sprain of joints and ligaments of elbow
ICD-10 codes.S53.0: Subluxation and dislocation of radial head
ICD-10 codes.S53.1: Subluxation and dislocation of ulnohumeral joint
ICD-10 codes.S53.2: Traumatic rupture of radial collateral ligament
ICD-10 codes.S53.3: Traumatic rupture of ulnar collateral ligament (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Patients may present weeks after the injury, or soon after surgical intervention
Major immediate and postsurgical concerns are elbow swelling and tenderness and nerve injuries
Recurrent instability or dislocation and posttraumatic elbow stiffness are common problems in chronic cases, and indicate a need for surgical intervention
Upper extremity function (mobility, strength) usually is reduced due to elbow pain and disuse

The treating physician may order restricted weight-bearing  (WB) status or limit ROM to a specific arc (typically the range in which the elbow joint remains stable) of the involved upper extremity. The patient may present wearing a hinged brace with an extension block to limit the ROM to within the safe range
Posttraumatic/post-surgical  wound healing may require surveillance, as indicated
Complicated cases may involve fracture (e.g., radial head, ulnar coronoid process) as well as associated shoulder, wrist, and hand injuries
Elbow deformity may be present if there is residual displacement
Chronic elbow extension deficit often develops from scar contracture and muscle shortening, especially of the biceps and brachialis Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Request instructions from physician regarding elbow joint stability, precautions for mobilization (e.g., limits for elbow extension), and expected outcome
Obtain specific WB instructions from physician

In nonoperative cases, elbow/forearm evaluation (for initiation of active ROM) usually is postponed until at least 2to 10 days post injury and reduction. Immobilization longer than 3 weeks negatively impacts outcomes. In surgical cases, assessment of active-assisted elbow flexion and extension and forearm pronation and supination generally is postponed until at least 3 to 5 days after surgery(1,8,11)
Stop the examination and immediately report signs and symptoms suggestive of neurovascular compromise to physician (e.g., if sensation is impaired or distal pulses are absent)
Observe for signs of dislocation/fracture displacement and report to physician

Notify physician of positive findings for upper extremity complications possibly related to the current elbow injury, including: –adhesive capsulitis –subacromial impingement –rotator cuff pathology –glenohumeral subluxation, acromioclavicular separation, clavicle fracture –impaired joint mobility of the wrist or hand –complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS;formerly called reflex sympathetic dystrophy) –DVT

causes: High-force  axial loading of the upper extremity is the most common mechanism of injury for posterior dislocations.Typically, the forearm is pronated and elbow extended, and the forearm supinates as the body rotates around the hand fixedon the ground(9)
The injury often occurs with a fall on an outstretched arm. The direction of the forces influences the direction of thedislocation(9)
Elbow dislocation may be caused by a sports-related  collision or fall in sports such as football, rollerblading,skateboarding, or wrestling(9)
Elbow trauma leading to dislocation may also be sustained in a motor vehicle accident (MV A) or fall on outstretched handfrom height or standing(9)
pathogenesis: Complex dislocations involve injury to soft tissue (i.e., capsule and ligamentous structures) as well as fractures of theelbow bones (i.e., radial head, distal humerus, proximal ulna(9)

Complex elbow dislocations may include:(9)–Fractures of the radial head/neck or coronoid process of ulna–Avulsion fractures of the lateral or medial epicondyles of the humerus–Comminution of the olecranon process or distal humerus–Cartilaginous injuries–Posttraumatic stiffness with limitation of elbow extension; typically, a 10–15°  loss of motion–Neurovascular injuries–Heterotopic bone formation (occurs in less than 5% of patients following elbow dislocation)

Complications will vary depending upon the nature of the injury–Authors of a case series designed to assess outcomes of open elbow dislocations found that in patients treated withsurgical debridement and open reduction and repair of soft tissues, 52% had postoperative complications. Complicationsincluded neurovascular injury, delayed fracture healing, pseudoarthrosis, and periarticular ossifications(5)
risk factors ,: Collision sports (e.g., American football, rugby, soccer)
Activities with increased risk of falling (e.g., rock climbing, bouldering,(4) skating, horseback or bicycle riding)
Adults involved in high fall-risk  activities (e.g., workers on ladders/elevated platforms, climbers) and ambulatory frail olderadults
More common in males than females (estimated incidence 53% and 47% respectively)
Balance issues; falling from a standing height is a common cause of injury

overall contraindications precautions: Consult physician for instructions on duration of immobilization, which will vary depending upon post-reduction  stability or surgical management
Avoid aggressive passive elbow joint manipulation throughout rehabilitation period
Report symptoms of acute illness (e.g., fever, chills, night sweats, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea) to physician
Consult physician in cases with unexpected inflammation, infection, or poor healing of soft tissues
Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a contraindication to exercising the involved limb

Older adults may require multidisciplinary rehabilitation or special considerations for examination and treatment, such as those with: mobility restrictions, neurological disease, or cardiopulmonary disease reduced cognitive function (e.g., brain trauma or dementia) depression and anxiety
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Request instructions from physician regarding elbow joint stability, precautions for mobilization (e.g., limits for elbow extension), and expected outcome
Obtain specific WB instructions from physician

In nonoperative cases, elbow/forearm evaluation (for initiation of active ROM) usually is postponed until at least 2to 10 days post injury and reduction. Immobilization longer than 3 weeks negatively impacts outcomes. In surgical cases, assessment of active-assisted elbow flexion and extension and forearm pronation and supination generally is postponed until at least 3 to 5 days after surgery(1,8,11)
Stop the examination and immediately report signs and symptoms suggestive of neurovascular compromise to physician (e.g., if sensation is impaired or distal pulses are absent)
Observe for signs of dislocation/fracture displacement and report to physician

Notify physician of positive findings for upper extremity complications possibly related to the current elbow injury, including: –adhesive capsulitis –subacromial impingement –rotator cuff pathology –glenohumeral subluxation, acromioclavicular separation, clavicle fracture –impaired joint mobility of the wrist or hand –complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS;formerly called reflex sympathetic dystrophy) –DVT

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document the date of the injury and circumstances (see Causes , above) resulting in the elbow injury. Is the dominant arm involved? Is there any underlying bone disease?

course of treatment.medical management: In nonoperative cases, document initial findings (e.g., type of dislocation, radiographic findings) and treatment, including reduction procedure and outcome. Document instructions for elbow protection, including WB status. Immobilization with a posterior splint (e.g., standard plaster splint or dynamic orthosis) typically is ordered for 2 to 10 days(1,8) Authors of an RCT conducted in the Netherlands comparing early mobilization (n = 48) and cast immobilization for 3 weeks (n = 52) found that both treatments had the same outcome at 1 year; however, patients treated with the early mobilization protocol returned to work and other activities sooner than those treated with immobilization(6) Early mobilization consisted of initiation of AROM at 2 days post injury and PROM/stretching at 3 weeks. Immobilization was cast immobilization for 3 weeks followed by initiation of a standard ROM protocol However, authors of a prospective trial of 60 nonsurgical cases in Senegal found that early mobilization was associated with severe pain and swelling, although functional outcomes were good to excellent in 90% of patients at onemonth postdislocation.  Only 19% of those immobilized for 21 days compared to 95% of those immobilized for 10 days had good to excellent outcomes at one month(9)
surgical management: Surgical management: Document date of surgery, type of fracture, procedures performed (including hardware used, repairs to tendon, ligament, or nerve), and instructions for postoperative WB and ROM
course of treatment.medications: Document medications prescribed for this injury. Are they being taken as prescribed?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Document radiographic findings. Stress X-rays  may be taken in patients with residual instability
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document any noted aggravating ADLs and factors that improve comfort
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much )
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (AM, mid-day, PM, night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, changes in sensation, significant increases in pain)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient have a history of breathing difficulty or require use of supplemental oxygen? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ /No__ -If Yes, describe

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document any prior upper extremity dislocations or fractures, especially those related to falls
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other health concerns, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports that will be contraindicated during the healing phase? What is the patient’s occupation? Is the patient able to work at present? Could the patient return to work with accommodations or adaptations?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient have limitations in performing ADLs? If so, document the problems and assistance/adaptive equipment/adaptive techniques provided
social and occupational history.living environment: Does the patient require modifications in the home to facilitate independence in ADLs?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: If the injury was related to the patient’s body size or physical capacity, document height, weight, and BMI
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the condition and fit of the patient’s cast, brace (static or hinged), or splint, if applicable. Does patient require devices to complete ADLs?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess dynamic balance as indicated by cause of fracture, especially if patient is at risk for falls. Administer functional reach test or Berg Balance Scale, as appropriate
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Confirm that distal pulses are intact, especially in cases with significant swelling/hematoma/hemarthrosis Assess peripheral sensory and motor function. Document specific deficits in cases of nerve impingement/injuryAssess edema at elbow and forearm as indicated using girth measurementObserve body mechanics for compensatory mechanisms and substitution during course of evaluation. Are ergonomic modifications needed for the patient to continue working?When full WB, assess upper extremity function in transfers, as well as mobility in occupational and recreational activitiesPostpone elbow joint accessory motion assessment until discharge. Assess elbow for joint stability and quality of mobility. Note the presence of bony block from heterotopic ossification or malunion. Does hardware impingement reduce joint mobility? Expect reduced joint mobility due to joint capsule restriction following prolonged disuse. Assess for joint stability after healing with the lateral pivot-shift  test, posterolateral rotatory apprehension test, and drawer test
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Postpone manual muscle testing (MMT) of elbow or radioulnar joint muscles until cleared by physician. Assess wrist and shoulder strength using MMT while protecting elbow joint. Assess grip strength with dynamometer. Expect disuse atrophy with weakness and inhibition of elbow flexors and extensors
observation inspection palpation includi: skin/scar assessment for healing and contracture
contracture (biceps, triceps, wrist flexors, and wrist extensors)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess alignment of elbow joint and upper extremity in general
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Postpone assessment of active and passive elbow ROM according to physician’s instructions. Assess active-assisted  elbow ROM in pain-free  range. On initial examination, assess ROM of upper extremity joints other than elbow (and radioulnar joints if involved). Assess elbow extension when cleared for active ROM. Measurements should be taken with a goniometer
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess biceps, triceps, and brachioradialis deep-tendon  reflexes. Postpone in case of an existing wound that involves the tendonAssess self-care  ADLs (e.g., upper and lower body dressing, eating, hygiene). Use objective testing (e.g., Barthel Index)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess upper extremity for sensation (e.g., light touch, static/dynamic 2-point  discrimination). Expect reduced sensation over sites of scarring. Assess elbow proprioception when cleared for active ROM
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Patient-reported outcomes for upper limb function include the Upper Limb Function Scale (ULFS) and the Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure –For additional information on the DASH, see  Clinical Review…Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) ;T903177
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: Assess upper extremity coordination, especially if dominant side is involved

contraindications precautions: full extension may be restricted (degree based on joint stability), but typically full ROM is allowed by 34 weeks post injury/surgery(7)
Avoid applying cold over superficial nerves, areas of diminished sensation or poor circulation, or slow-healing wounds
Use caution with patients who are hypertensive, as cold can cause a transient increase in blood pressure; discontinue treatment if there is an elevation in blood pressure
Use caution with patients who are hypersensitive to cold
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Use of cryotherapy with patients who have an aversion to cold may be counterproductive if being used to promote muscle relaxation and decrease pain
Stimulation through or across the chest
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
over the region of a cardiac pacemaker
over the pelvic, abdominal, and lumbar regions during pregnancy
in an area with infection or bleeding
if a tumor or malignancy is present in the area
in the area of a DVT or thrombophlebitis
over the heart, stellate, or cervical ganglia
over epiphyseal plates of growing bones
Use caution in patients with sensory deficits and in patients who are unable to communicate sensory deficits
Use caution if patient has circulatory impairments
Use caution over plastic or metal implants
Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
other: Implement gentle active-assisted,  pain-free  elbow ROM according to physician’s orders on limitation of range.(8,9) Initially,
To reduce stress on elbow lateral collateral ligament, perform elbow ROM exercises with shoulder in slight external rotation while avoiding passive shoulder abduction with internal rotation(2)
To prevent elbow and shoulder contractures, discourage routine use of shoulder sling and/or splint after 2 weeks(1,2)

Evidence is lacking to recommend for or against the use of physical or electrotherapeutic modalities in elbow rehabilitation, although modalities may be trialed for pain management.(2,3) Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or the specific protocol of a clinic

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions include the following, although in some cases ( when approved by the treating physician ) electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk:(3)
Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications; do not use:(3)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Elbow dislocation (may include fracture)/pain, edema, and wound management; prevention of contractures; restoration of elbow function for return to regular ADLs/IADLs
assessment plan of care.rule out: Physician may exclude elbow fracture, unstable reduction, stress fracture, adhesive capsulitis, compartment syndrome, heterotopic ossification, CRPS, DVT, rotator cuff pathology, triceps or biceps avulsion, myositis dissecans, neuropathic arthropathy, posttraumatic osteoarthritis in older adults
prognosis: Patients with uncomplicated dislocations usually have satisfactory results
Patients who develop chronic dislocation have a worse prognosis and often have residual stiffness, recurrent instability, and functional deficits following treatment(13)
Prolonged splinting (more than 2–3 weeks) and immobilization is associated with reduced elbow mobility, contracture, and increased duration of disability(1,8)
See Clinical Review…Fracture, Elbow , referenced above, for prognosis of patients with elbow fracture dislocation.
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Acupuncturist for unremitting pain Orthotist for custom splint or brace (not able to be fabricated by the therapist) Physician for complications, such as recalcitrant stiffness or swelling
treatment summary: In both nonoperative and surgical cases, follow physician’s instructions for therapy

Immobilization in 90° elbow flexion usually is required for 2 to 10 days to allow for healing time. The length of immobilization will be based on the stability of the elbow. Stiffness following immobilization is a significant complication and longer periods of immobilization result in more stiffness. Following immobilization, use of an articulating brace allowing progressive degrees of mobilization over time may be initiated.A major goal of rehabilitation is to restore elbow mobility in a safe arc of ROM while optimizing joint stability(8,12)

Treatment should include protection of injured tissues to promote healing, control of pain and edema, maintenance of ROM of uninvolved joints (hand, wrist, and shoulder), strengthening the upper extremity, functional training, and patient

stabilization of elbow joint: Patient feedback on joint stability during ADLs
normal sensation: Reassessment of sensation, proprioception, and coordination

maintenance or prevention: Avoid painful activities that aggravate elbow
Continue therapeutic exercise plan to maintain the highest achievable elbow ROM, strength, and functional mobility
Use elbow protectors for risky sports, as indicated
patient education: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons website, “Elbow Dislocation,” https://orthoinfo.aaos.org/en/diseases--conditions/elbow-dislocation

Orthopedic Trauma Association website, “Elbow Dislocation,” https://ota.org/for-patients/find-info-body-part/3718  Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
